heading: Stinger Spiritborn Leveling Guide
content: Welcome to the Stinger Spiritborn Leveling Guide! This build relies on and focuses on high damage output to unleash devastating explosions with the Key Passive. While is a melee ground-targeted attack, it has the special perk that it hits all nearby enemies, giving it a pseudo-ranged AoE all around you. In addition to the itself, it can also trigger , an effect created and amplified by various . Luckily, the most important aspect can be unlocked from Dungeons, giving this build an easy start. Even though this setup sports potent damage over time effects, we also scale direct hit damage and critical strike synergies to get the most out of our hits. In addition, this build brings one of the coolest skills in the game to the table: . We use this ultimate from the start until we enter the endgame in Torment 1. While this guide brings you into Torment difficulties with ease, this is only the beginning. Once all of the synergies are unlocked from following the you eventually ascend into an unstoppable AoE machine that reminds of the good old Hammerdin days. Let's get started! The Season 9 theme is the . This season allows you to craft unique using three different components: a , and three through the Seasonal Questline, and can be found while exploring . You choose a Skill as the trigger for your . Once in Torment I or higher, can be crafted, which replace the Gems in your Jewelry, adding additional power to your build. because it has a short cooldown and combines well with to break walls and disable Chilling Wind affixes. To start off you have to put 2 points into Basic Skills to unlock the other sections. is your choice to generate resources and apply a decent DoT effect while doing so. Once you reach level 15, this is replaced with to reset the Evade cooldown, synergizing with our Spirit Hall choice. is your main ability which has the great perk that it can hit any enemy in approximately half a screen radius, giving you great coverage as long as you infect everything. Together with once you find it), you spawn spiraling from the center of the impact which eventually become the core part of your damage output. is a costly skill and for a while in the early game you have to rely on your Basic Skill to generate Vigor. Passives like help a great deal early on, later you also pick up . In addition, there are a range of useful legendary resource aspects you can find on jewelry, so keep an eye out for and Vigor per Second rolls on your Helm, Chest and Boots. is a staple for early game Spiritborn mobility. Use it whenever you can to go from pack to pack or close the distance to your target. is used for the early game to increase your mobility further but is eventually replaced once you have more base movement speed. At level 15, you can unlock your class mechanic called Spirit Hall. There you may choose one out of the four spirit guardians for both the primary and secondary slots. In this case, you go with (primary) and (secondary). The first allows your evade to shoot out feathers that deal a good amount of flat damage and apply . Remember to switch to to reset your cooldown more often and try to get boots with "Attacks reduce Evade cooldown" on them to benefit from this effect even more. It also allows you to pick up Eagle passives such as . The second hall bonus gives you easy access to for extra attack speed and cooldown resets. is your key passive of choice. It converts your effects from damage over time into instant-damage explosions, consuming the DoT on the target. Together with the rest of your kit, this Key Passive creates an absolute AoE monster, so most of the optimizations in this build are tailored towards single-target damage from this point forward. To get the combo to work, aim for some rolls of Critical Strike Chance on your gear. is your ultimate until you reach endgame. You already bring some Poison synergies to buff it and while active it usually takes care of most enemies on its own. Unfortunately, it falls off in the lategame and we replace it with at max level for the stacks and other benefits provides. Regardless of which skill you're using, you benefit from passives such as for more damage. At this point, most of the key synergies are unlocked and the gameplay loop is almost complete. As you level up, you unlock a lot of extra points that go into various offensive and defensive passives or max out certain skills. Check out the skills progression above to see where to put your points as you go, but feel free to deviate from the order displayed as necessary. For example, you can pick up earlier for extra defense or leave out some of the Ultimate passive cluster nodes until later if you find yourself rarely using The endgame build looks different from the leveling build due to additional synergies you unlock later. Among other small adjustments on the tree, you need more defense so you replace . Second, your basic attack gets replaced by and you switch your primary spirit hall bonus to . Find out more details in the allows to use as a free damage cooldown that also applies for attack speed and to trigger Once you reach level 15, you have to complete a short questline starting in . A Priority Quest leads you there to help out . After a few stops outside of town you have to enter the Sacred Hunting Grounds and defeat the Spirit Beast. While inside this dungeon you have to use the emote wheel at two separate stops, once for "Help", once for "Thanks" in order to progress. The boss fight is relatively long and difficult for low level characters, so it's recommended to do this quest on normal. After finishing the quest your secondary Spirit Hall unlocks automatically at level 30. To get started as a Stinger Spiritborn, focus the most on upgrading your weapon as its damage is the base for all further damage calculations. Otherwise, follow the priority list below. While you don't have all of the desired temper manuals available, simply try to get anything useful on your gear until you acquire the right ones. For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. Tempering low level gear is relatively cheap and the results can be very impactful. For the early game, Elemental Surge Weapon Tempers are very powerful due to their high base damage, especially if you are twinking. If you find these, you may want to keep imprinting them on your weapons for an easy time. is a collection of you can imprint onto items at the . They unlock after completing specific located around Sanctuary or salvaging items with these powers. Check out our to locate these Dungeons. For leveling, there are a few powers that can significantly help us if we have the funds to imprint them. In addition, keep an eye out for powerful items you may find for this or other builds. As you level up, you may get lucky and find some great random drops. Some of these can massively amplify your power and speed up the leveling by switching to another build. Keep in mind that there are many more that can be useful to multiple builds; this just lists some of the most impactful ones. While we usually recommend starting with Endgame Builds at level 60, you often can make them work earlier with these drops: You can have up to two Runewords in your setup, each consisting of one Rune. Socket them in Two-Handed Weapons if your build calls for them, otherwise place them into your Armor pieces to replace normal gems. The Stinger Spiritborn focuses on the following combos: If you have access to higher level runes, you can also explore the following options: are unlocked during the Vessel of Hatred campaign and assist you in battle. There are 4 separate Mercenaries to choose from, each with their own skill trees and abilities. You can have one (permanent) mercenary during solo play and a who assists you from time to time in certain situations. He provides us with extra All Resistances, regularly applies an extra damage buff through and prevents us from getting oneshot every 30 seconds thanks to . Beware that he's not present when playing in groups, so make sure you remain resistance capped without him. for extra damage reduction. In Diablo 4, you can level by completing the Campaign, collecting Grim Favors for the , completing activities, grinding , fighting in the or interacting with the . While there are many ways to level up in Diablo 4, not all of them are equal. As you approach level 60 with the Stinger Spiritborn, you unlock higher item power gear that represents a massive jump in character power. This is a good time to refresh your setup with new tempers and imprints. At level 60, unlock. Work towards Tier 10 to enter Torment 1, where the Endgame begins. Focus on overcapping your Armor (1000+) and Resistances (75%+) as you receive some penalties to your character's stats: At this point, your setup should look roughly like this before you dive into min/maxing with . With better gear, more levels and , you can push further and eventually unlock higher difficulties for increased rewards. This step marks the end of the leveling guide. Below is the Paragon setup to get you started in Torment difficulty, but ideally, you should now transition towards the endgame version of this build or choose another of your liking. Use the slider to see progression steps. At around Paragon 200, leveling slows down significantly and all important nodes and Glyph sockets should be unlocked. Afterwards, you can min/max your build with minor tweaks and by picking up additional smaller nodes. Some Glyph position swaps, board changes and other pathing adjustments may occur as you unlock your full potential. The setup displayed by default is the final version of the build before spending additional points that do not significantly impact your character's power. This video is still largely the same as the written guide. The Stinger Spiritborn creates a fun mix of explosions and a Hammerdin feel with that decimate everything in its path.

For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. Tempering low level gear is relatively cheap and the results can be very impactful. For the early game, Elemental Surge Weapon Tempers are very powerful due to their high base damage, especially if you are twinking. If you find these, you may want to keep imprinting them on your weapons for an easy time. is a collection of you can imprint onto items at the . They unlock after completing specific located around Sanctuary or salvaging items with these powers. Check out our to locate these Dungeons. For leveling, there are a few powers that can significantly help us if we have the funds to imprint them. In addition, keep an eye out for powerful items you may find for this or other builds. As you level up, you may get lucky and find some great random drops. Some of these can massively amplify your power and speed up the leveling by switching to another build. Keep in mind that there are many more that can be useful to multiple builds; this just lists some of the most impactful ones. While we usually recommend starting with Endgame Builds at level 60, you often can make them work earlier with these drops: You can have up to two Runewords in your setup, each consisting of one Rune. Socket them in Two-Handed Weapons if your build calls for them, otherwise place them into your Armor pieces to replace normal gems. The Stinger Spiritborn focuses on the following combos: If you have access to higher level runes, you can also explore the following options: are unlocked during the Vessel of Hatred campaign and assist you in battle. There are 4 separate Mercenaries to choose from, each with their own skill trees and abilities. You can have one (permanent) mercenary during solo play and a who assists you from time to time in certain situations. He provides us with extra All Resistances, regularly applies an extra damage buff through and prevents us from getting oneshot every 30 seconds thanks to . Beware that he's not present when playing in groups, so make sure you remain resistance capped without him. for extra damage reduction. In Diablo 4, you can level by completing the Campaign, collecting Grim Favors for the , completing activities, grinding , fighting in the or interacting with the . While there are many ways to level up in Diablo 4, not all of them are equal. As you approach level 60 with the Stinger Spiritborn, you unlock higher item power gear that represents a massive jump in character power. This is a good time to refresh your setup with new tempers and imprints. At level 60, unlock. Work towards Tier 10 to enter Torment 1, where the Endgame begins. Focus on overcapping your Armor (1000+) and Resistances (75%+) as you receive some penalties to your character's stats: At this point, your setup should look roughly like this before you dive into min/maxing with . With better gear, more levels and , you can push further and eventually unlock higher difficulties for increased rewards. This step marks the end of the leveling guide. For example, you can pick up earlier for extra defense or leave out some of the Ultimate passive cluster nodes until later if you find yourself rarely using The endgame build looks different from the leveling build due to additional synergies you unlock later. Among other small adjustments on the tree, you need more defense so you replace . Second, your basic attack gets replaced by and you switch your primary spirit hall bonus to . Find out more details in the allows to use as a free damage cooldown that also applies for attack speed and to trigger Once you reach level 15, you have to complete a short questline starting in . A Priority Quest leads you there to help out . After a few stops outside of town you have to enter the Sacred Hunting Grounds and defeat the Spirit Beast. While inside this dungeon you have to use the emote wheel at two separate stops, once for "Help", once for "Thanks" in order to progress. The boss fight is relatively long and difficult for low level characters, so it's recommended to do this quest on normal. After finishing the quest your secondary Spirit Hall unlocks automatically at level 30. To get started as a Stinger Spiritborn, focus the most on upgrading your weapon as its damage is the base for all further damage calculations. Otherwise, follow the priority list below. While you don't have all of the desired temper manuals available, simply try to get anything useful on your gear until you acquire the right ones. For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. Tempering low level gear is relatively cheap and the results can be very impactful. For the early game, Elemental Surge Weapon Tempers are very powerful due to their high base damage, especially if you are twinking. If you find these, you may want to keep imprinting them on your weapons for an easy time. is a collection of you can imprint onto items at the . They unlock after completing specific located around Sanctuary or salvaging items with these powers. Check out our to locate these Dungeons. For leveling, there are a few powers that can significantly help us if we have the funds to imprint them. In addition, keep an eye out for powerful items you may find for this or other builds. As you level up, you may get lucky and find some great random drops. Some of these can massively amplify your power and speed up the leveling by switching to another build. Keep in mind that there are many more that can be useful to multiple builds; this just lists some of the most impactful ones. While we usually recommend starting with Endgame Builds at level 60, you often can make them work earlier with these drops: You can have up to two Runewords in your setup, each consisting of one Rune. Socket them in Two-Handed Weapons if your build calls for them, otherwise place them into your Armor pieces to replace normal gems. The Stinger Spiritborn focuses on the following combos: If you have access to higher level runes, you can also explore the following options: are unlocked during the Vessel of Hatred campaign and assist you in battle. There are 4 separate Mercenaries to choose from, each with their own skill trees and abilities. You can have one (permanent) mercenary during solo play and a who assists you from time to time in certain situations. He provides us with extra All Resistances, regularly applies an extra damage buff through and prevents us from getting oneshot every 30 seconds thanks to . Beware that he's not present when playing in groups, so make sure you remain resistance capped without him. for extra damage reduction. In Diablo 4, you can level by completing the Campaign, collecting Grim Favors for the , completing activities, grinding , fighting in the or interacting with the . While there are many ways to level up in Diablo 4, not all of them are equal. As you approach level 60 with the Stinger Spiritborn, you unlock higher item power gear that represents a massive jump in character power. This is a good time to refresh your setup with new tempers and imprints. At level 60, unlock. Work towards Tier 10 to enter Torment 1, where the Endgame begins. Focus on overcapping your Armor (1000+) and Resistances (75%+) as you receive some penalties to your character's stats: At this point, your setup should look roughly like this before you dive into min/maxing with . With better gear, more levels and , you can push further and eventually unlock higher difficulties for increased rewards. This step marks the end of the leveling guide. This video is still largely the same as the written guide. The Stinger Spiritborn creates a fun mix of explosions and a Hammerdin feel with that decimate everything in its path.

Use it whenever you can to go from pack to pack or close the distance to your target. is used for the early game to increase your mobility further but is eventually replaced once you have more base movement speed. At level 15, you can unlock your class mechanic called Spirit Hall. There you may choose one out of the four spirit guardians for both the primary and secondary slots. Remember to switch to to reset your cooldown more often and try to get boots with "Attacks reduce Evade cooldown" on them to benefit from this effect even more. It also allows you to pick up Eagle passives such as . The second hall bonus gives you easy access to for extra attack speed and cooldown resets. is your key passive of choice. It converts your effects from damage over time into instant-damage explosions, consuming the DoT on the target. Together with the rest of your kit, this Key Passive creates an absolute AoE monster, so most of the optimizations in this build are tailored towards single-target damage from this point forward. To get the combo to work, aim for some rolls of Critical Strike Chance on your gear. is your ultimate until you reach endgame. A Priority Quest leads you there to help out . After a few stops outside of town you have to enter the Sacred Hunting Grounds and defeat the Spirit Beast. While inside this dungeon you have to use the emote wheel at two separate stops, once for "Help", once for "Thanks" in order to progress. The boss fight is relatively long and difficult for low level characters, so it's recommended to do this quest on normal. After finishing the quest your secondary Spirit Hall unlocks automatically at level 30. To get started as a Stinger Spiritborn, focus the most on upgrading your weapon as its damage is the base for all further damage calculations. Otherwise, follow the priority list below. While you don't have all of the desired temper manuals available, simply try to get anything useful on your gear until you acquire the right ones. For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. Tempering low level gear is relatively cheap and the results can be very impactful. For the early game, Elemental Surge Weapon Tempers are very powerful due to their high base damage, especially if you are twinking. If you find these, you may want to keep imprinting them on your weapons for an easy time. is a collection of you can imprint onto items at the . They unlock after completing specific located around Sanctuary or salvaging items with these powers. Check out our to locate these Dungeons. For leveling, there are a few powers that can significantly help us if we have the funds to imprint them. In addition, keep an eye out for powerful items you may find for this or other builds. As you level up, you may get lucky and find some great random drops. Some of these can massively amplify your power and speed up the leveling by switching to another build. Keep in mind that there are many more that can be useful to multiple builds; this just lists some of the most impactful ones. While we usually recommend starting with Endgame Builds at level 60, you often can make them work earlier with these drops: You can have up to two Runewords in your setup, each consisting of one Rune. Socket them in Two-Handed Weapons if your build calls for them, otherwise place them into your Armor pieces to replace normal gems. The Stinger Spiritborn focuses on the following combos: If you have access to higher level runes, you can also explore the following options: are unlocked during the Vessel of Hatred campaign and assist you in battle. There are 4 separate Mercenaries to choose from, each with their own skill trees and abilities. You can have one (permanent) mercenary during solo play and a who assists you from time to time in certain situations. He provides us with extra All Resistances, regularly applies an extra damage buff through and prevents us from getting oneshot every 30 seconds thanks to . Beware that he's not present when playing in groups, so make sure you remain resistance capped without him. for extra damage reduction. In Diablo 4, you can level by completing the Campaign, collecting Grim Favors for the , completing activities, grinding , fighting in the or interacting with the . While there are many ways to level up in Diablo 4, not all of them are equal. As you approach level 60 with the Stinger Spiritborn, you unlock higher item power gear that represents a massive jump in character power. This is a good time to refresh your setup with new tempers and imprints. At level 60, unlock. Work towards Tier 10 to enter Torment 1, where the Endgame begins. Focus on overcapping your Armor (1000+) and Resistances (75%+) as you receive some penalties to your character's stats: At this point, your setup should look roughly like this before you dive into min/maxing with . With better gear, more levels and , you can push further and eventually unlock higher difficulties for increased rewards. This step marks the end of the leveling guide. As you approach level 60 with the Stinger Spiritborn, you unlock higher item power gear that represents a massive jump in character power. This is a good time to refresh your setup with new tempers and imprints. At level 60, unlock. Work towards Tier 10 to enter Torment 1, where the Endgame begins. Focus on overcapping your Armor (1000+) and Resistances (75%+) as you receive some penalties to your character's stats: At this point, your setup should look roughly like this before you dive into min/maxing with . heading: Ultimate Cluster
content: . This season allows you to craft unique using three different components: a , and three through the Seasonal Questline, and can be found while exploring . You choose a Skill as the trigger for your . Once in Torment I or higher, can be crafted, which replace the Gems in your Jewelry, adding additional power to your build. because it has a short cooldown and combines well with to break walls and disable Chilling Wind affixes. To start off you have to put 2 points into Basic Skills to unlock the other sections. is your choice to generate resources and apply a decent DoT effect while doing so. Once you reach level 15, this is replaced with to reset the Evade cooldown, synergizing with our Spirit Hall choice. is your main ability which has the great perk that it can hit any enemy in approximately half a screen radius, giving you great coverage as long as you infect everything. Together with once you find it), you spawn spiraling from the center of the impact which eventually become the core part of your damage output. is a costly skill and for a while in the early game you have to rely on your Basic Skill to generate Vigor. Passives like help a great deal early on, later you also pick up . In addition, there are a range of useful legendary resource aspects you can find on jewelry, so keep an eye out for and Vigor per Second rolls on your Helm, Chest and Boots. is a staple for early game Spiritborn mobility. Use it whenever you can to go from pack to pack or close the distance to your target. is used for the early game to increase your mobility further but is eventually replaced once you have more base movement speed. At level 15, you can unlock your class mechanic called Spirit Hall. There you may choose one out of the four spirit guardians for both the primary and secondary slots. In this case, you go with (primary) and (secondary). The first allows your evade to shoot out feathers that deal a good amount of flat damage and apply . Remember to switch to to reset your cooldown more often and try to get boots with "Attacks reduce Evade cooldown" on them to benefit from this effect even more. It also allows you to pick up Eagle passives such as . The second hall bonus gives you easy access to for extra attack speed and cooldown resets. is your key passive of choice. It converts your effects from damage over time into instant-damage explosions, consuming the DoT on the target. Together with the rest of your kit, this Key Passive creates an absolute AoE monster, so most of the optimizations in this build are tailored towards single-target damage from this point forward. To get the combo to work, aim for some rolls of Critical Strike Chance on your gear. is your ultimate until you reach endgame. You already bring some Poison synergies to buff it and while active it usually takes care of most enemies on its own. Unfortunately, it falls off in the lategame and we replace it with at max level for the stacks and other benefits provides. Regardless of which skill you're using, you benefit from passives such as for more damage. At this point, most of the key synergies are unlocked and the gameplay loop is almost complete. As you level up, you unlock a lot of extra points that go into various offensive and defensive passives or max out certain skills. A Priority Quest leads you there to help out . After a few stops outside of town you have to enter the Sacred Hunting Grounds and defeat the Spirit Beast. While inside this dungeon you have to use the emote wheel at two separate stops, once for "Help", once for "Thanks" in order to progress. The boss fight is relatively long and difficult for low level characters, so it's recommended to do this quest on normal. After finishing the quest your secondary Spirit Hall unlocks automatically at level 30. To get started as a Stinger Spiritborn, focus the most on upgrading your weapon as its damage is the base for all further damage calculations. Otherwise, follow the priority list below. While you don't have all of the desired temper manuals available, simply try to get anything useful on your gear until you acquire the right ones. For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. Tempering low level gear is relatively cheap and the results can be very impactful. For the early game, Elemental Surge Weapon Tempers are very powerful due to their high base damage, especially if you are twinking. If you find these, you may want to keep imprinting them on your weapons for an easy time. is a collection of you can imprint onto items at the . They unlock after completing specific located around Sanctuary or salvaging items with these powers. Check out our to locate these Dungeons. For leveling, there are a few powers that can significantly help us if we have the funds to imprint them. In addition, keep an eye out for powerful items you may find for this or other builds. As you level up, you may get lucky and find some great random drops. Some of these can massively amplify your power and speed up the leveling by switching to another build. Keep in mind that there are many more that can be useful to multiple builds; this just lists some of the most impactful ones. While we usually recommend starting with Endgame Builds at level 60, you often can make them work earlier with these drops: You can have up to two Runewords in your setup, each consisting of one Rune. Socket them in Two-Handed Weapons if your build calls for them, otherwise place them into your Armor pieces to replace normal gems. You can have one (permanent) mercenary during solo play and a who assists you from time to time in certain situations. Beware that he's not present when playing in groups, so make sure you remain resistance capped without him. for extra damage reduction. For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. In addition, there are a range of useful legendary resource aspects you can find on jewelry, so keep an eye out for and Vigor per Second rolls on your Helm, Chest and Boots. is a staple for early game Spiritborn mobility. Use it whenever you can to go from pack to pack or close the distance to your target. is used for the early game to increase your mobility further but is eventually replaced once you have more base movement speed. At level 15, you can unlock your class mechanic called Spirit Hall. There you may choose one out of the four spirit guardians for both the primary and secondary slots. In this case, you go with (primary) and (secondary). The first allows your evade to shoot out feathers that deal a good amount of flat damage and apply . Remember to switch to to reset your cooldown more often and try to get boots with "Attacks reduce Evade cooldown" on them to benefit from this effect even more. It also allows you to pick up Eagle passives such as . The second hall bonus gives you easy access to for extra attack speed and cooldown resets. is your key passive of choice. It converts your effects from damage over time into instant-damage explosions, consuming the DoT on the target. Together with the rest of your kit, this Key Passive creates an absolute AoE monster, so most of the optimizations in this build are tailored towards single-target damage from this point forward. To get the combo to work, aim for some rolls of Critical Strike Chance on your gear. is your ultimate until you reach endgame. You already bring some Poison synergies to buff it and while active it usually takes care of most enemies on its own. Unfortunately, it falls off in the lategame and we replace it with at max level for the stacks and other benefits provides. Regardless of which skill you're using, you benefit from passives such as for more damage. At this point, most of the key synergies are unlocked and the gameplay loop is almost complete. As you level up, you unlock a lot of extra points that go into various offensive and defensive passives or max out certain skills. Check out the skills progression above to see where to put your points as you go, but feel free to deviate from the order displayed as necessary. For example, you can pick up earlier for extra defense or leave out some of the Ultimate passive cluster nodes until later if you find yourself rarely using The endgame build looks different from the leveling build due to additional synergies you unlock later. Among other small adjustments on the tree, you need more defense so you replace . Second, your basic attack gets replaced by and you switch your primary spirit hall bonus to . Find out more details in the allows to use as a free damage cooldown that also applies for attack speed and to trigger Once you reach level 15, you have to complete a short questline starting in . A Priority Quest leads you there to help out . After a few stops outside of town you have to enter the Sacred Hunting Grounds and defeat the Spirit Beast. While inside this dungeon you have to use the emote wheel at two separate stops, once for "Help", once for "Thanks" in order to progress. The boss fight is relatively long and difficult for low level characters, so it's recommended to do this quest on normal. After finishing the quest your secondary Spirit Hall unlocks automatically at level 30. To get started as a Stinger Spiritborn, focus the most on upgrading your weapon as its damage is the base for all further damage calculations. Otherwise, follow the priority list below. While you don't have all of the desired temper manuals available, simply try to get anything useful on your gear until you acquire the right ones. For example, % Damage, Damage to Close, Vulnerable Damage, etc. all work as long as you activate their conditions. Likewise, you can temper multiple defensive options such as Resistances, Life, Armor to fill gaps in your survivability. Tempering low level gear is relatively cheap and the results can be very impactful. For the early game, Elemental Surge Weapon Tempers are very powerful due to their high base damage, especially if you are twinking. If you find these, you may want to keep imprinting them on your weapons for an easy time. is a collection of you can imprint onto items at the . They unlock after completing specific located around Sanctuary or salvaging items with these powers. Check out our to locate these Dungeons. For leveling, there are a few powers that can significantly help us if we have the funds to imprint them. In addition, keep an eye out for powerful items you may find for this or other builds. As you level up, you may get lucky and find some great random drops. Some of these can massively amplify your power and speed up the leveling by switching to another build. Keep in mind that there are many more that can be useful to multiple builds; this just lists some of the most impactful ones. While we usually recommend starting with Endgame Builds at level 60, you often can make them work earlier with these drops: You can have up to two Runewords in your setup, each consisting of one Rune. Socket them in Two-Handed Weapons if your build calls for them, otherwise place them into your Armor pieces to replace normal gems. The Stinger Spiritborn focuses on the following combos: If you have access to higher level runes, you can also explore the following options: are unlocked during the Vessel of Hatred campaign and assist you in battle. There are 4 separate Mercenaries to choose from, each with their own skill trees and abilities. You can have one (permanent) mercenary during solo play and a who assists you from time to time in certain situations. He provides us with extra All Resistances, regularly applies an extra damage buff through and prevents us from getting oneshot every 30 seconds thanks to . Beware that he's not present when playing in groups, so make sure you remain resistance capped without him. for extra damage reduction. In Diablo 4, you can level by completing the Campaign, collecting Grim Favors for the , completing activities, grinding , fighting in the or interacting with the . While there are many ways to level up in Diablo 4, not all of them are equal. As you approach level 60 with the Stinger Spiritborn, you unlock higher item power gear that represents a massive jump in character power. This is a good time to refresh your setup with new tempers and imprints. At level 60, unlock. Work towards Tier 10 to enter Torment 1, where the Endgame begins. Focus on overcapping your Armor (1000+) and Resistances (75%+) as you receive some penalties to your character's stats: At this point, your setup should look roughly like this before you dive into min/maxing with . With better gear, more levels and , you can push further and eventually unlock higher difficulties for increased rewards. This step marks the end of the leveling guide. Below is the Paragon setup to get you started in Torment difficulty, but ideally, you should now transition towards the endgame version of this build or choose another of your liking. Use the slider to see progression steps. At around Paragon 200, leveling slows down significantly and all important nodes and Glyph sockets should be unlocked. Afterwards, you can min/max your build with minor tweaks and by picking up additional smaller nodes. Some Glyph position swaps, board changes and other pathing adjustments may occur as you unlock your full potential. The setup displayed by default is the final version of the build before spending additional points that do not significantly impact your character's power. This video is still largely the same as the written guide. The Stinger Spiritborn creates a fun mix of explosions and a Hammerdin feel with that decimate everything in its path.
